RooPie

Class ROI

  • java.lang.Object
    • RooPie.ROI

  • public class ROI
extends java.lang.Object
    Implements the Roomba Open Interface to the 500 series using RXTX. The document is available here: http://cfpm.org/~peter/bfz/iRobot_Roomba_500_Open_Interface_Spec.pdf setting up the pi to use the serial port is here: http://www.elinux.org/RPi_Serial_Connection and the RXTX package with instructions is available here: http://rxtx.qbang.org/wiki/index.php/Main_Page.

    • Field Detail

      • BUMPS

        public static final int BUMPS
        packet ids as per the iRobot Roomba 500 Open Interface Spec. These return single values; Group packet ids (0-6,100-107) are returned as an array that uses these to index individual packets

      • disconnect

        public void disconnect()
        Disconnect the serial port. Under linux you will get a stale lock if this is not called before turning things off.

      • start

        public void start()
           throws java.io.IOException
        This command starts to OI. You must always send the Start command before sending any other commands to the OI.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • baud

        public void baud(int code)
          throws java.io.IOException
        This command sets the baud rate in bits per second at which OI commands an data are sent according to the baud code sent in the data byte. The default baud rate at power up is 115200 bps, but the starting baud rate can be changed to 19200 by holding down the Clean button while powering on Roomba until you hear a sequence of decending tones. Once the baud rate is changed, it persists until Roomba is power cycled by pressing the power button or removing the battery, or when the battery voltage falls below the minimum required for processor operation. You must wait 100ms after sending this command before sending additional commands at the new baud rate.

        Baud codes - 0: 300, 1:600, 2:1200, 3:2400, 4:4800, 5:9600, 6:14400, 7:19200, 8:28800, 9:38400, 10:57600, 11:115200

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • passive

        public void passive()
             throws java.io.IOException
        This command puts the OI in Passive mode. Note it is identical to the start command.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • safe

        public void safe()
          throws java.io.IOException
        This command puts the OI into Safe mode, enabling the user control of Roomba. It turns off all LEDs. The OI can be in Passive, Safe, or Full mode to accept this command. If a safety condition occurs (see above) Roomba reverts automatically to Passive mode.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • full

        public void full()
          throws java.io.IOException
        This command gives you complete control over Roomba by putting the OI into Full mode, and turning off the cliff, wheel-drop and internal charger safety features. That is, in Full mode, Roomba executes any command that you send it, even if the internal charger is plugged in, or command triggers a cliff or wheel drop condition.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

        public void clean()
           throws java.io.IOException
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • schedule

        public void schedule(int days,
            int sunHour,
            int sunMinute,
            int monHour,
            int monMinute,
            int tueHour,
            int tueMinute,
            int wedHour,

            int thrMinute,
            int friHour,
            int friMinute,
            int satHour,
            int satMinute)
              throws java.io.IOException
        This command sends Roomba a new schedule. To disable scheduled cleaning, send all 0s. (Days is a mistery - 40 is used in the examples)
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • setDayTime

        public void setDayTime(int day,
              int hour,
              int minute)
                throws java.io.IOException
        This command sets Roomba's clock. Day: 0 - 6 (Sunday - Saturday) hour:0-23 minute:0-59
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • power

        public void power()
           throws java.io.IOException
        This command powers down Roomba.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • drive

        public void drive(int vel,
         int radius)
           throws java.io.IOException
        This command controls Roomba's drive wheels. It takes two integers, the first specifies the average velocity of the drive wheels in millimeters per second (-500 to 500). The next specify the radius in millimeters at which Roomba will turn (-2000 to 2000). Special cases: Straight = 32768 or 32767 (hex 8000 or 7FFF), Turn in place = -1 (clockwise) or 1 (counter-clockwise)
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • drivePwm

        public void drivePwm(int left,
            int right)
              throws java.io.IOException
        This command lets you control the raw forward and bckward motion of Roomba's drive wheels independently. Valid range is -255 to 255. A positive PWM makes that wheel drive forward, while a negative PWM makes it drive backward.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • pwmMotors

        public void pwmMotors(int main,
             int side,
             int vac)
               throws java.io.IOException
        This command lets you control the speed of Roomba's main brush, and vacuum independently. With each data byte, you specify the duty cycle for the low side driver (max 128). For example, if you want to control a motor with 25\% of battery voltage, choose a duty cycle of 128 * 25\% = 32. The main brush and side brush can be run in either direction. The vocuum only runs forward. Positive speeds turn the motor in its default (cleaning) direction. Default direction for the side brush is counterclockwise. Default direction for the main brush/flapper is inward.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • leds

        public void leds(int ledBits,
        int color,
        int intensity)
          throws java.io.IOException
        This command controls the LEDs common to all models of Roomba 500. The Clean/Power LED is specified by two data bytes: one for the colour and the other for the intensity.
        • letBits can be one of CHECKROBOT,DOCK,SPOT or DEBRIS, or any combination bit or-ed together eg DOCK|DEBRIS
        • color can be 0-255. 0 = green, 255 = red. Intermediate values give intermdediate colors (orange, yellow, etc)
        • intensity can be 0-255. 0 = off, 255 = full intensity.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • buttons

        public void buttons(char which)
             throws java.io.IOException
        This command lets you push Roomba's buttons. The buttons will automatically release after 1/6th of a second.

        bit 7:clock 6:schedule 5:day 4:hour 3:minute 2:dock 1:spot 0:clean

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • song

        public void song(int songNumber,
        int[] notes,
        int[] durations)
          throws java.io.IOException
        This command lets you specify up to four songs to the OI that you can play at a later time. Each song is associated with a song number. The play command uses the song number to identify your song selection. Each song can contain up to sixteen notes. Each note is associated with a note number that uses MIDI note definitions and a duration that is specified in 64ths of a second. The number of data bytes varies, depending on the length of the song specified. A one note song is specified by four data bytes. For each additional note within a song, add two data bytes.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • play

        public void play(int songNumber)
          throws java.io.IOException
        This command lets you select a song to play from the songs added to Roomba using the Song command. You must add one or more songs to Roomba using the Song command in order for the Play command to work.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • sensors

        public int sensors(int pid)
            throws java.io.IOException
        This command requests the OI to send a single sensor value (packets 7-58 inclusive) as specified in the ROI.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • sensors

        public int[] sensors(int groupPacketId,
            int[] results)
              throws java.io.IOException
        This command requests the OI to send a Group Packet and returns the buffer with the individual packets assigned. The first arg is the required group (0-6,100-107) and the second is an int array into which the individual packets should be put. It is this array that is returned. If a value in the array is not set by the group, then its value is left as is. Note the second arg needs to be atleast 59 long.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • queryList

        public int[] queryList(int[] packets,
              int[] results)
                throws java.io.IOException
        This command lets you ask for a list of sensor packets. The result is returned once, as in the Sensors command. The robot returns the packets in the order you specify.

        the first arg is the list of packets required; the second arg is the place to put the values for those packets. The return value is the second argument.

        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • stream

        public int[] stream(int[] packets)
             throws java.io.IOException
        This command starts a stream of data packets. The list of packets requested is sent every 15ms, which is the rate Roomba uses to update data. It is up to the user to ensure that the number of packets can be sent in 15ms at the current baud rate - see the ROI specification document for details.

        Data is returned in an array, A, where A[x] is the reading on the sensor, x, where x = AMPS,ANGLE ... WALL_SIG. Note all sensor values are integers, some are signed, some are not; some are two bytes, some are one. All are converted to conventional java int values. The returned array is internal - don't try and modify or set it.

        Only the last call to the method counts, and a call to stream(new int[0]) means no packets are sent until stream(...) is called again. A call to pauseResumeStream() will put on hold any updates to the internal array - no data is sent from the roomba until pauseResumeStream is called again, allowing time for other commands/sensor packets to be sent.

        If the data is corrupted, the result will have a non zero value in position 0,

        1. checksum failed
        2. wrong packet ID (corrupt data - something else causing Roomba to send stuff?)
        3. there was too much data so it probably wasn't sent in the last 15 ms
        4. failed to get the header when expected - syncronizing
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • pauseResumeStream

        public void pauseResumeStream()
                       throws java.io.IOException
        This command lets you stop and restart the stream without clearing the list of requested packets.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
